title: Normal Saline
content:
Packaging

  • Usually a 1000 ml flexible, non-latex plastic bag
  • Not in drug bags or caches

Indications

  • Solution for fluid and electrolyte replenishment
  • Hypovolemia
  • Shock
  • Flushing of wounds
  • Pulmonary edema with systolic BP over 100 mmHg
  • Sepsis

Adult Dosing

  • Non traumatic shock without pulmonary edema: 500 ml IV, may repeat up to two times if needed
  • Non traumatic shock with pulmonary edema: 250 ml IV
  • Sepsis: 1 L IV, Additional IV fluid if indicated
  • Penetrating trauma to chest or abdomen: enough fluid to obtain a radial pulse
  • If BGL reads over 400 mg/dL or "High" on glucometer, administer 500 ml fluid IV - wide open.
  • Crush syndrome: Initial treatment: 1 L IV then 500 ml/hour IV. If hypotensive and the patient has been trapped more than 1 hour, then additional 1 L IV
  • Heat exposure: 500 ml IV, may repeat one time. Additional IV fluid, if indicated

Pediatric Dosing

  • 20 ml/kg IV bolus
  • In heat exposures, may repeat 20/ml/kg IV bolus
  • In shock, call for orders to administer additional fluid

Therapeutic Action

  • Used for hydration and management of hypotension

Contraindications

  • None in the emergency setting

Precautions And Side Effects

  • None

title: Ondansetron
content:
Packaging

  • 4 mg in 2 ml vial, (2 mg/ml) - 1 vial in drug bag
  • 4 mg tablet - 1 tablet in drug bag

Indications

  • For nausea or active vomiting

Adult Dosing

  • For the AEMT and Paramedic: 4 mg tablet PO
  • For the Paramedic: 4 mg slow IV, preferred route for active vomiting as patient may need hydration. If no IV, may use 4 mg tablet PO. Consider administering 4 mg (2 ml) of the IV form by discharging into the patient's mouth.

Pediatric Dosing

  • For the AEMT and the Paramedic: 4 mg tablet PO if patient 12 y/o or older and weight is 40 kg or more. Transport time should be considered prior to administration.
  • For the Paramedic: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg) if patient 12 y/o or older and weight is 40 kg or more.

Therapeutic Action

  • Stimulation of 5-HT 3 receptors causes transmission of sensory signals to the vomiting center via vagal afferent fibers to induce vomiting.
  • By binding to 5-HT 3 receptors, Ondansetron blocks vomiting mediated by serotonin release.

Contraindications

  • Known hypersensitivity to Ondansetron

Precautions And Side Effects

  • During pregnancy it should only be used where clearly needed.
  • Ondansetron (Zofran) is NOT to be given prophylactically with Naloxone.
  • Side effects: Constipation or diarrhea, Fever, Headache, Sudden blindness of 2-3 minutes duration. (the speed of delivery may contribute to the blindness)

Protocols

  • Medical Protocol 4001-Abdominal Pain

title: Oral Glucose
content:
Packaging

  • Tube; concentration varies, check label
  • Not carried in drug bag

Indications

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Generalized hypothermia without arrest
  • Altered level of consciousness of unknown cause
  • Seizures with BGL of less than 60 mg/dl, no BGL monitor; or suspicion of hypoglycemia despite BGL reading
  • For the AEMT and Paramedic, no IV access

Adult Dosing

  • 1 tube
  • May be repeated in 10 minutes if BGL remains less than 50 mg/dl

Pediatric Dosing

  • 1 tube
  • May be repeated in 10 minutes if BGL remains less than 60 mg/dl

Therapeutic Action

  • Raise blood glucose concentration

Contraindications

  • Inability to control the airway

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Use caution when giving to unresponsive patients.
  • Hyperglycemia

Protocols

  • Medical Protocol 4008- Diabetic Emergencies - Hypoglycemia

title: Pralidoxime
content:
Packaging

  • 600 mg auto-injector

Indications

  • To be used following Atropine in organophosphate, or nerve agent poisoning.
  • Both for treatment of civilian patients at the scene, as well as for protection of public safety personnel who walk into scene & become unexpectedly contaminated.

Adult Dosing

  • 600 mg IM auto-injector

Pediatric Dosing

  • Patients greater than 20 kg: 600 mg IM auto-injector

Therapeutic Action

  • Reactivates cholinesterase after poisoning with anticholinesterase agents, (Organophosphate or Nerve Gas)
  • Reverses muscle paralysis after organophosphate poisoning

Contraindications

  • Hypersensitivity

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Use with caution in myasthenia gravis, renal impairment, pregnancy, children
  • Can spread to child through breast feeding

Protocols

  • Special Operations Protocol 6002-Antidote Resources
  • Special Operations Protocol 6005- Organophosphate or Nerve Agent Exposure

title: Sodium Bicarbonate
content:
Packaging

  • 50 mEq in 50 ml syringe (1 mEq/ml)
  • Two in drug bag

Indications

  • Not for routine arrests. Studies indicate no proven efficacy.
  • Renal dialysis patient in asystole or PEA cardiac arrest
  • Excited delirium patients that go into cardiac arrest
  • Known tricyclic overdose
  • Crush Syndrome

Adult Dosing

  • Cardiac Arrest: In renal dialysis patient: 100 mEq IV. Consider for the excited delirium patient who goes into arrest: 100 mEq IV
  • Tricyclic Antidepressant OD: 100 mEq IV. May repeat dose of 50 mEq IV for persistent or prolonged QRS
  • Crush Syndrome: 100 mEq IV

Pediatric Dosing

  • Cardiac Arrest: In renal dialysis patient: 1 mEq/kg IV
  • Tricyclic Antidepressant OD: 1 mEq/kg IV. May repeat dose of 0.5 mEq/kg IV for persistent or prolonged QRS
  • Crush Syndrome: 1 mEq/kg IV

Therapeutic Action

  • Buffers metabolic acidosis

Contraindications

  • None in the emergency setting

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypoxia
  • Rise in intracellular PCO2 and increased tissue acidosis
  • Electrolyte imbalance (hypernatremia)
  • Seizures
  • Tissue sloughing at injection site

title: Sodium Nitrite
content:
Packaging

  • 300 mg in 10 ml vial (30 mg/ml)
  • Available in caches located in each county in Homeland Security Region 3.

Indications

  • Patients with known or suspected cyanide poisoning

Adult Dosing

  • 300 mg (10 ml) 3% solution slow IV

Pediatric Dosing

  • Not indicated in pediatric patients

Therapeutic Action

  • Oxidizes hemoglobin which then combines with cyanide to form an inactive compound

Contraindications

  • Nitrite/nitrate allergy

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Methemoglobinemia if given in excessive amounts

Protocols

  • Trauma Protocol 3008 - Cyanide Poisoning & Antidotes

title: Sodium Thiosulfate
content:
Packaging

  • 12.5 gm in 50 ml vial (250 mg/ml)
  • Available in caches located in each county in Homeland Security Region 3.

Indications

  • Conscious patient with known or suspected cyanide poisoning
  • Smoke inhalation with suspected cyanide component
  • Cardiac arrest from known or suspected cyanide poisoning or smoke inhalation

Adult Dosing

  • 12.5 gm (50 ml) 25% solution slow IV

Pediatric Dosing

  • Greater than 25 kg: 12.5 gm (50 ml) 25% solution slow IV
  • Less than 25 kg: 412.5 mg/kg (1.65 ml/kg) of 25% solution (max dose 12.5 g (50 ml))

Therapeutic Action

  • Accelerates detoxification of cyanide

Contraindications

  • None

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Possible hypotension

Protocols

  • Trauma Protocol 3008 - Cyanide Poisoning & Antidotes

title: Tetracaine
content:
Packaging

  • 0.5%/ml eye drop bottle (10 ml)
  • One in drug bag

Indications

  • Prior to eye irrigation in cases of chemical injury to the eye and in other situations with significant eye pain without possibility of penetrating trauma to eye.

Adult Dosing

  • 2 drops in each affected eye

Pediatric Dosing

  • 2 drops in each affected eye

Therapeutic Action

  • Provides rapid, brief, superficial anesthesia by inhibiting conduction of nerve impulses from sensory nerves

Contraindications

  • Hypersensitivity to Tetracaine
  • Open injury to eye

Precautions And Side Effects

  • May cause burning or stinging sensation or irritation
  • Can cause epithelial damage and systemic toxicity
  • Incompatible with mercury or silver salts often found in ophthalmic products

Protocols

  • Trauma Protocol 3011 - Eye Injuries

title: Tranexamic Acid (TXA)
content:
Packaging

  • 1 gram in 10 ml vial (100 mg/ml)
  • Two in drug bag

Indications

  • Known or suspected hemorrhage secondary to trauma
  • Time since injury is known to be less than 3 hours
  • Uncontrolled post-partum hemorrhage

Adult Dosing

  • 2 gm IV/IO over 1-2 minutes

Pediatric Dosing

  • In pediatric patients with uncontrolled bleeding from a recent tonsillectomy, TXA nebulized: Less than 25 kg: 250 mg, nebulized with 3 ml normal saline, O2 flowing at 8-10 LPM. 25 kg or greater: 500 mg, nebulized with 3 ml normal saline, O2 flowing at 8-10 LPM

Therapeutic Action

  • An anti-fibrinolytic and the synthetic equivalent of the amino acid lysine
  • Inhibits both plasminogen activation and plasmin activity
  • Prevents clot breakdown and reduces hemorrhage

Contraindications

  • Hypersensitivity
  • Pediatric patients, unless treating uncontrolled bleeding from a recent tonsillectomy
  • Time elapsed from initial injury is greater than 3 hours or otherwise unknown
  • Known or suspected pregnancy of greater than 20 weeks
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Do not delay transport for administration of Tranexamic Acid (TXA)
  • It is important to accurately note the time of administration
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances may occur
  • Monitor patient for hypotension usually found in rapid infusions
  • Side effects: Nausea, Vomiting, Visual disturbances, Seizure

Protocols

  • Trauma Protocol 3015 Hemorrhage Control
  • Medical Protocol 4006 - Childbirth with Complications

title: Vasopressin
content:
Packaging

  • 20 units in 1 ml vial, 20 units/ml
  • Usually 2 vials (20 ml) present
  • Not routinely present in the drug bag

Indications

  • Adult patients in cardiac arrest

Adult Dosing

  • 40 units IV
  • Once IV is established, Vasopressin is permitted after either first or second dose of Epinephrine.

Pediatric Dosing

  • Not indicated in pediatric patients

Therapeutic Action

  • Potent peripheral vasoconstrictor.
  • May be used as an alternative pressor to Epinephrine in the treatment of adult shock-refractory VF and PEA

Contraindications

  • None in the adult cardiac arrest

Precautions And Side Effects

  • May produce cardiac ischemia and angina

Protocols
